skill.name: baoyu-url-to-markdown
skill.description: Fetch any URL and convert to markdown using Chrome CDP. Supports two modes - auto-capture on page load, or wait for user signal (for pages requiring login). Use when user wants to save a webpage as markdown.
skill.summary: Convert any webpage to clean markdown using Chrome CDP browser automation
skill.author: jimliu

security_audit.summary: All 148 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The skill uses Chrome CDP for legitimate browser automation to convert webpages to markdown. Network operations are localhost-only (Chrome debug port), spawn is for launching Chrome (expected for CDP), and file operations are for reading Chrome paths and writing output files. No credential access, no data exfiltration, no malicious intent.

content.value_statement: Converts any webpage to clean markdown using Chrome browser automation. Supports dynamic pages requiring login and outputs structured markdown with metadata.
actual_capabilities: Fetches any URL and renders it with full JavaScript support via Chrome CDP
Converts HTML to clean markdown with proper formatting for headers, lists, links, tables, and code blocks
Extracts metadata including title, description, author, and publication date
Supports two capture modes: auto-capture on page load and wait-for-user signal for login-protected pages
Saves output to organized directory structure by domain
limitations: Requires Chrome or Chromium browser to be installed
Cannot bypass paywalls or access content behind authentication without manual login via wait mode
May not perfectly preserve complex layouts or deeply nested HTML structures
Output quality depends on the source page HTML structure

use_cases.title: Archive Article Content
use_cases.description: Save blog posts, news articles, or documentation pages as markdown for offline reading or archival purposes.

use_cases.title: Extract Documentation
use_cases.description: Convert online documentation and technical guides to markdown for inclusion in personal knowledge bases or project documentation.

use_cases.title: Capture Login-Protected Pages
use_cases.description: Use wait mode to manually log in to websites, then capture the authenticated content as markdown.

prompt_templates.title: Basic URL to Markdown
prompt_templates.scenario: Quick conversion of a public webpage

prompt_templates.title: With Output Path
prompt_templates.prompt: Save this article as markdown to a specific file: <url> -o ~/docs/article.md
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need the output in a specific location

prompt_templates.title: Wait Mode for Login Pages
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert this protected page using wait mode so I can log in first: <url> --wait

prompt_templates.title: Capture Complex Pages
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert this dynamic page with lazy loading content: <url> --wait --timeout 60000
prompt_templates.scenario: Single-page applications or pages with infinite scroll

output: description: "Learn the basics of markdown formatting"
Markdown is a lightweight markup language...
You can create headers using hash symbols...

best_practices: Use --wait mode for pages with lazy-loaded content, authentication, or complex JavaScript rendering
Increase --timeout for slow-loading pages (e.g., --timeout 60000 for 60 seconds)
Store markdown files in version control to track changes in captured content over time
Check output quality after capture and re-run with --wait if content is missing
anti_patterns: Converting pages behind paywalls without authorization - this may violate terms of service
Running automated captures without --wait on pages requiring login - content will be inaccessible
Ignoring timeout errors on complex pages - increase timeout or use --wait mode instead
Expecting pixel-perfect layout preservation - markdown is for content, not visual fidelity

faq.question: Does this work with JavaScript-heavy single-page applications?
faq.answer: Yes. Chrome CDP renders full JavaScript. For complex SPAs, use --wait mode to allow full page load, or increase --timeout.

faq.question: Can I convert pages that require login?
faq.answer: Yes. Use --wait mode. The script will pause after opening the browser, letting you log in manually. Press Enter when ready to capture.

faq.question: What happens to images in the output?
faq.answer: Images are preserved as markdown image references with their original URLs. For offline use, you would need to download images separately.

faq.question: How is the output file named?
faq.answer: Files are saved to url-to-markdown/<domain>/<slug>.md. The slug is derived from the page title or URL path. Timestamps are added if files already exist.

faq.question: Can I use a custom Chrome path?
faq.answer: Yes. Set the URL_CHROME_PATH environment variable to point to your Chrome executable.

faq.question: What markdown features are supported?
faq.answer: Headers (H1-H6), bold, italic, strikethrough, links, images, code blocks, blockquotes, ordered and unordered lists, and tables.
